subject: Re: [junit] JUnit not matching to my needs - execute order sh ows design flaw ?
msgSnippet: ... Curt, just because it s not the solution you had in mind doesn t make it a kludge . (The implication is that the solution isn t really a solution at all,
messageBody:
Curt Sampson wrote:

> On Mon, 12 Jul 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > To me, that sounds like a test results filtering problem, so I would put
> > my attention there for a simple solution. An XSL stylesheet that looks
> > for that one test result and highlights failures in big, bold red
> > letters would be easy (we know how to do it), and effective, if not
> perfect.
>
> I think that's not too bad a kludge, actually, though I'd really prefer
> to have the information closer to the tests.

Curt, just because it's not the solution you had in mind doesn't make it
a "kludge". (The implication is that the solution isn't really a
solution at all, and the further implication is that I'm just too lazy
to solve the problem. I don't like that.) You stated your problem as "I
want it to be obvious that test 125 failed so that I can ignore the
other failures." You did not state as a requirement that those other
tests ought not to execute. What I suggest is a full-blown solution to
your problem as stated. :)

> However, what about those of us who work with the command-line testrunner?

Build your own test runner that listens for that failure and alerts you
specially somehow. I think that suggestion puts me in the "A" category. :)

Once you have other, more complicated dependencies to deal with, add
some kind of rules engine to the test runner that allows you to collect
"key results" -- that is, the list of results you check first before
looking at the rest. Something like that.

Take care.
